questions.question_text:
An engineering team must allow communications between a new two-tier application in a Cisco Application-Centric Infrastructure environment.
Which two elements must be configured to allow communications between two endpoint groups that represents the application? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Contract and Filter
Contract and Filter
Contract is the answer as per cisco recommended ARCH300-320 test

GRE over IPSec will be more suitable for this solution. Connection should be done only between 2 sites, and GRE over IPSec is simpler in implementation then GET VPN + there is a need to have only 2 public IPs to allow tunnel to be created and LAN it self can use a Private Prefix.

GETVPN also provides for multicast and encryption. However GETVPN is tunnel less and as such requires all IPs, even LAN subnetys, be routable over the Internet. That will be an expensive option . GRE over IPSEC just requires 1 public IP at each sute, LAN can be private IP. May even be possible to use Public IP at one site and DDNS at other site.
D. GRE over IPSEC provides support for encryption and multicast.
It's D GRE over IPsec

questions.question_text:
A network engineer must use an Internet connection to provide backup connectivity between two sites. The backup connection must be encrypted and support multicast.
Which technology must be used?

An engineer is designing a multitenant network that requires separate management access and must share a single physical firewall.
Which two features support this design? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
answers are correct, as per https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa96/configuration/general/asa-96-general-config/ha-contexts.html#ID-2171-0000015b
Multiple context mode does not support the following features:
RIP
OSPFv3. (OSPFv2 is supported.)
Multicast routing
Threat Detection
Unified Communications
QoS

OSPFv2 is dynamic and site-to-site is possible, so I believe the answer is correct.

qos, multicast routing, threat detection, unified communications all aren't supported in multi-context mode. See https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa95/configuration/general/asa-95-general-config/ha-contexts.pdf.

differs once again. not sure about this one...
https://www.aoowe.com/demo/20170711/300-320-389-QS-Cisco-Designing-Cisco-Network-Service-Architectures-ARCH-By-Kerwin.pdf

Best practice is for 3 controllers, however ACI fabric will continue to operate when all controllers are failed. 

1 APIC for me

I found this:

The APIC cluster is comprised of multiple APIC controllers that provide operators a unified real time monitoring, diagnostic, and configuration management capability for the ACI fabric. To assure optimal system performance, follow the guidelines below for making changes to the APIC cluster.
Cisco recommends that you have at least 3 active APICs in a cluster, along with additional standby APICs. A cluster size of 3, 5, or 7 APICs is recommended. A cluster size of 4 or 6 APICs is not recommended.
1 should be correct following ARCH Foundation Learning Guide.

"Three or more Cisco APIC controllers that are dual-connected to different leaf switches for maximum resilience. Note that the fabric is manageable even with just one controller and operational without a controller."
Designing for Cisco Network Service Architectures (ARCH) Foundation Learning Guide, Fourth Edition.
I believe the answer is 1 controller. My 2 cents.

Unless you can't make changes until the cluster is fully fit and restored to 3 members?

https://community.cisco.com/t5/application-centric/apic-cluster-why-minimum-of-3-controllers/td-p/2614489

questions.question_text:
While troubleshooting an Application Centric network cluster, an engineer sees that an APIC has gone offline.
What is the minimum number of APICs required for a production ACI fabric to continue to operate?

choices.A: Advertise all routes to both ISPs.
choices.C: Accept all inbound routes from the ISPs.
choices.D: Filter routes inbound from the ISPs.
choices.B: Filter routes outbound to the ISPs.

questions.question_text: When a site has Internet connectivity with two different ISPâ€™s, which two strategies are recommended to avoid becoming a BGP transit site? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
https://www.noction.com/knowledge-base/bgp-filtering
inbound loose' and 'strict option filtering as well as out so torn on this one still but i would based on this go: B + D
B & C are correct answers
I also think that the correct answers should be B and C.

There is no need to Filter Inbound routes from ISP as we want to receive all available paths from them, but we need to filter outbound routes to not advertise Prefixes received from ISP 1 to ISP 2 and vice versa. B and C are correct.
Should be B & C. All inbound routes from the ISP should be accepted.
I think should be B, C
